Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> `364            return this->chainPower.nHeight;`

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @SHossain very useful debug info, i am not sure that `chainPower` should be used, and i don't think this is hush-specific bug

Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @SHossain if you tried to do all of this in the same GUI with a diff asset chain, it would happen in KMD core

Content: [dscrd-hush] <SHossain> yes, we assumed that üòÉ

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <SHossain> i notified jl777 as well

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> chainPower is a verus thing

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> it's being used when it shouldn't be

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> which is causing this massive failure

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> `this->chainPower` is undefined, so trying to look for the `nHeight` entry inside of it, blows up

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> chainPower is only when there is mixed PoS/PoW, iirc

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> but I have not reviewed all these changes that came from VRSC into KMD

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @SHossain this may also be a bug in VRSC itself, or just in how it was merged to KMD

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @SHossain the core issue is that `GetHeight` assumes `this->chainPower` always has been set, and that is not the case here

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <SHossain> I'll ping Miketout as well in this case

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-hush] <SHossain> @dukeleto getting this crash
```
Linux
Building cclib to src/
LINUX
gcc -Wno-write-strings -DBUILD_ROGUE -std=c++11 -I../../depends/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/include -I../univalue/include -I../cryptoconditions/include -I../cryptoconditions/src -I../cryptoconditions/src/asn -I.. -I. -fPIC -shared -O0 -D _DEBUG -o librogue.so -c cclib.cpp
In file included from ../cc/eval.h:22:0,
                 from cclib.cpp:22:
../chain.h: In member function ‚Äòint32_t CBlockIndex::GetHeight() const‚Äô:
../chain.h:364:22: error: could not convert ‚Äò((const CBlockIndex*)this)->CBlockIndex::chainPower‚Äô from ‚Äòconst CChainPower‚Äô to ‚Äòbool‚Äô
         return this->chainPower ? this->chainPower.nHeight : 0;
                ~~~~~~^~~~~~~~~~
Makefile_rogue:22: recipe for target 'librogue.so' failed
make: *** [librogue.so] Error 1
ROGUE BUILD FAILED
```

Author: Gateway#3763

and the output is your WIF for the new chain```

Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @Inevitability with your new WIF, you could import that into the CLI wallet, if you really wanted to learn a bit

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> i think i saw you using the binaries already, iirc

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> `hush-cli importprivkey SUPER_SEKRET_PRIVKEY`

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> that's it, and then you can use `hush-cli getwalletinfo` to see your updated balance with that private key added to your wallet

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> using CLI wallets might not be as fun, but when things break and go really wrong in a GUI wallet, knowing how the insides work is extremely valuable to anybody, not only developers
